paper_abstract: Given a finite alphabet Sigma and a language L subset of Sigma(+), the centralizer of L is defined as the maximal language commuting with it. We prove that if the primitive root of the smallest word of L (with respect to a lexicographic order) is prefix distinguishable in L then the centralizer of L is as simple as possible, that is, the submonoid L-star. This lets us obtain a simple proof of a known result concerning the centralizer of nonperiodic three-word languages.
paper_title: On the simplest centralizer of a language
